text: Comptroller of the Currency
label: HH1

text: Administrator of National Banks
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C.  20219
label: BODY

text: Corporate Decision #97-72
label: HH1

text: August 1997
label: TITLE

text: DECISION OF THE OFFICE OF THE COMPTROLLER OF THE CURRENCY
label: HH1

text: ON THE APPLICATION TO MERGE
label: HH2

text: FIRST AMERICAN BANK, N.A., LISBON, NORTH DAKOTA,
label: BODY

text: WITH AND INTO
label: HH2

text: FIRST AMERICAN BANK, N.A., MOORHEAD, MINNESOTA
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH2

text: On May 21, 1997, an Application was filed with the Office of the Comptroller of the
label: BODY

text: Currency ("OCC") for approval to merge First American Bank, National Association, Lisbon,
label: BODY

text: North Dakota ("Lisbon Bank") with and into First American Bank, National Association,
label: BODY

text: Moorhead, Minnesota ("Moorhead Bank"), under the charter and title of the latter, under 12
label: BODY

text: U.S.C. §§ 215a-1, 1828(c) & 1831u(a) ("the Merger Application").  Moorhead Bank has its main
label: BODY

text: office in Moorhead, Minnesota.  It also has a branch in Moorhead, Minnesota.  Lisbon Bank has
label: BODY

text: its main office in Lisbon, North Dakota, and operates branches in North Dakota.  In the Merger
label: BODY

text: Application, OCC approval is also requested for the resulting bank to retain Moorhead Bank's
label: BODY

text: main office as the main office of the resulting bank under 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(d)(1), and to retain
label: BODY

text: Moorhead Bank's branch and Lisbon Bank's main office and branches, as branches after the
label: BODY

text: merger under 12 U.S.C. §§ 36(d) & 1831u(d)(1).
label: BODY

text: Both Lisbon Bank and Moorhead Bank are subsidiaries of Bremer Financial Corporation
label: BODY

text: ("Bremer"), a multistate bank holding company headquartered in St. Paul, Minnesota.  In the
label: BODY

text: proposed merger, two of Bremer's existing bank subsidiaries will be combined into one bank with
label: BODY

text: branches.  As of March 31, 1997, the Lisbon Bank had approximately $91.8 million in assets and
label: BODY

text: $75.8 million in deposits.  As of the same date, the Moorhead Bank had approximately $3.6
label: BODY

text: million in assets and $343,000 in deposits.
label: BODY

text: II.
label: HH1

text: LEGAL AUTHORITY
label: HH2

text: The Interstate Merger is Authorized under 12 U.S.C. §§ 215a-1 & 1831u.
label: BODY

text: For purposes of section 1831u, the following definitions apply:  The term "home State" means, with respect
label: BODY

text: to a national bank, "the State in which the main office of the bank is located."  The term "host State" means, "with
label: BODY

text: respect to a bank, a State, other than the home State of the bank, in which the bank maintains, or seeks to establish and
label: BODY

text: maintain, a branch."  The term "interstate merger transaction" means any merger transaction approved pursuant to section
label: BODY

text: 1831u(a)(1).  The term "out-of-State bank" means, "with respect to any State, a bank whose home State is another State."
label: BODY

text: The term "responsible agency" means the agency determined in accordance with 12 U.S.C. § 1828(c)(2) (namely, the
label: BODY

text: OCC if the acquiring, assuming, or resulting bank is a national bank).  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(f)(4), (5), (6), (8) & (10).
label: BODY

text: In 1994, Congress enacted legislation to create a framework for interstate mergers and
label: BODY

text: branching by banks.  See Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994,
label: BODY

text: Pub. L. No. 103-328, 108 Stat. 2338 (enacted September 29, 1994) ("the Riegle-Neal Act").  The
label: BODY

text: Riegle-Neal Act added a new section 44 to the Federal Deposit Insurance Act that authorizes
label: BODY

text: certain interstate merger transactions beginning on June 1, 1997.  See Riegle-Neal Act § 102(a)
label: BODY

text: (adding new section 44, 12 U.S.C. § 1831u).  It also made conforming amendments to the
label: BODY

text: provisions on mergers and consolidations of national banks to permit national banks to engage in
label: BODY

text: such section 44 interstate merger transactions.  See Riegle-Neal Act § 102(b)(4) (adding a new
label: BODY

text: section, codified at 12 U.S.C. § 215a-1).  It also added a similar conforming amendment to the
label: BODY

text: McFadden Act to permit national banks to maintain and operate branches in accordance with
label: BODY

text: section 44.  See Riegle-Neal Act § 102(b)(1)(B) (adding new subsection 12 U.S.C. § 36(d)).
label: BODY

text: Section 44 authorizes mergers between banks with different home states:
label: BODY

text: (1)  In General. -- Beginning on June 1, 1997, the responsible agency may
label: BODY

text: approve a merger transaction under section 18(c) [12 U.S.C. § 1828(c), the Bank
label: BODY

text: Merger Act] between insured banks with different home States, without regard to
label: BODY

text: whether such transaction is prohibited under the law of any State.
label: BODY

text: 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(a)(1).   The Act permits a state to elect to prohibit such interstate merger
label: BODY

text: transactions involving a bank whose home state is the prohibiting state by enacting a law between
label: BODY

text: September 29, 1994, and May 31, 1997, that expressly prohibits all mergers with all out-of-state
label: BODY

text: banks.  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(a)(2) (state "opt-out" laws).  In this Merger Application, the home
label: BODY

text: states of the banks are Minnesota and North Dakota; neither state has opted out.  Accordingly,
label: BODY

text: this Merger Application may be approved under 12 U.S.C. §§ 215a-1 & 1831u(a).
label: BODY

text: In addition, an application to engage in an interstate merger transaction under 12 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: § 1831u is also subject to certain requirements and conditions set forth in sections 1831u(a)(5) and
label: BODY

text: 1831u(b) of the Riegle-Neal Act.  These conditions are: (1) compliance with state-imposed age
label: BODY

text: limits, if any, subject to the Act’s limits; (2) compliance with certain state filing requirements,
label: BODY

text: to the extent the filing requirements are permitted in the Act; (3) compliance with nationwide and
label: BODY

text: state concentration limits; (4) community reinvestment compliance; and (5) adequacy of capital
label: BODY

text: and management skills.
label: BODY

text: The Merger Application satisfies all these conditions to the extent applicable.  First, the
label: BODY

text: proposal satisfies the state-imposed age requirements permitted by section 1831u(a)(5).  Under
label: BODY

text: that section, the OCC may not approve a merger under section 1831u(a)(1) "that would have the
label: BODY

text: Under this provision, states are permitted to impose a filing requirement on out-of-state banks that will operate
label: BODY

text: branches in the state as a result of an interstate merger transaction under the Riegle-Neal Act, but the states may impose
label: BODY

text: only those requirements that are within the terms specified.  Since Congress has specifically set forth and limited what
label: BODY

text: state filing requirements apply for these interstate transactions, it clearly intended that only those requirements would
label: BODY

text: apply, and the states may not impose others.  Thus, in a transaction involving only national banks, only the filing
label: BODY

text: requirements allowed under section 1831u(b)(1) must be complied with.  However, where a state bank is involved, a state
label: BODY

text: may continue to have authority to impose greater requirements on its own state-chartered banks, because of the
label: BODY

text: reservation of authority in section 1831u(c)(3).  Moreover, as a general matter, national banks are formed and
label: BODY

text: incorporated under, and governed by, federal law.  Their authority to enter mergers, to establish branches, or to undergo
label: BODY

text: other changes in their corporate existence is determined by federal law, not state law; and any requisite approval is by
label: BODY

text: the OCC, not state authorities.  For a fuller discussion of this subject, see, e.g., Decision on the Applications to Merge
label: BODY

text: First Interstate Banks into Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. (OCC Corporate Decision No. 96-29, June 1, 1996) (at pages 4-5,
label: BODY

text: effect of permitting an out-of-State bank or out-of-State bank holding company to acquire a bank
label: BODY

text: in a host state that has not been in existence for the minimum period of time, if any, specified in
label: BODY

text: the statutory law of the host State."  12 U.S.C. § 1831u(a)(5)(A).  In this Merger Application,
label: BODY

text: Moorhead Bank is acquiring by merger a bank (Lisbon Bank) in the host state of North Dakota.
label: BODY

text: The statutory laws of North Dakota do not contain any minimum age requirement.  Thus, the
label: BODY

text: Lisbon Bank/Moorhead Bank merger satisfies the Riegle-Neal Act requirement of compliance with
label: BODY

text: state age laws.
label: BODY

text: Second, the proposal meets the applicable filing requirements.  A bank applying for an
label: BODY

text: interstate merger transaction under section 1831u(a) must (1) "comply with the filing requirements
label: BODY

text: of any host State of the bank which will result from such transaction" as long as the filing
label: BODY

text: requirement does not discriminate against out-of-state banks and is similar in effect to filing
label: BODY

text: requirements imposed by the host state on out-of-state nonbanking corporations doing business in
label: BODY

text: the host state, and (2) submit a copy of the application to the state bank supervisor of the host
label: BODY

text: state.  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(1).   The North Dakota interstate banking statute provides that
label: BODY

text: an "out-of-state bank that will be the resulting bank pursuant to an interstate merger involving a
label: BODY

text: North Dakota bank must notify and submit a copy of its interstate merger application to the board
label: BODY

text: of the proposed merger not later than the date on which it files the application with the responsible
label: BODY

text: federal regulatory authority."  N.D. Cent. Code § 6-08.4-05 (1996).  As implemented to date,
label: BODY

text: the filing requirements of section 6-08.4-05 do not appear to discriminate against out-of-state
label: BODY

text: banks or to impose a filing requirement more burdensome than that imposed on nonbanking
label: BODY

text: corporations.  Moorhead Bank provided a copy of its OCC Merger Application to the North
label: BODY

text: Dakota state bank supervisor.  Thus, the Lisbon Bank/Moorhead Bank merger satisfies the Riegle-
label: BODY

text: Neal Act requirement of compliance with state filing requirements.
label: BODY

text: Third, the proposed interstate merger transaction does not raise issues with respect to the
label: BODY

text: deposit concentration limits of the Riegle-Neal Act.  Section 1831u(b)(2) places certain nationwide
label: BODY

text: and statewide deposit concentration limits on section 1831u(a) interstate merger transactions.
label: BODY

text: However, interstate merger transactions involving only affiliated banks are specifically excepted
label: BODY

text: from these provisions.  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(2)(E).  Lisbon Bank and Moorhead Bank are
label: BODY

text: affiliates; thus section 1831u(b)(2) is not applicable to this merger.
label: BODY

text: Fourth, the proposed interstate merger transaction also does not raise issues with respect
label: BODY

text: to the special community reinvestment compliance provisions of the Riegle-Neal Act.  In
label: BODY

text: determining whether to approve an application for an interstate merger transaction under section
label: BODY

text: 1831u(a), the OCC must (1) comply with its responsibilities under section 804 of the federal
label: BODY

text: Community Reinvestment Act ("CRA"), 12 U.S.C. § 2903, (2) take into account the CRA
label: BODY

text: evaluations of any bank which would be an affiliate of the resulting bank, and (3) take into
label: BODY

text: account the applicant banks' record of compliance with applicable state community reinvestment
label: BODY

text: laws.  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(3).  However, this provision does not apply to mergers between
label: BODY

text: affiliated banks since it applies only "for an interstate merger transaction in which the resulting
label: BODY

text: bank would have a branch or bank affiliate immediately following the transaction in any State in
label: BODY

text: which the bank submitting the application (as the acquiring bank) had no branch or bank affiliate
label: BODY

text: immediately before the transaction."  12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(3).  See also H.R. Conf. Rep. No.
label: BODY

text: 651, 103d Cong., 2d Sess. 52 (1994).  In this Merger Application, Moorhead Bank (the bank
label: BODY

text: submitting the application as the acquiring bank) has a bank affiliate in North Dakota before the
label: BODY

text: transaction (i.e., Lisbon Bank), and is also not otherwise obtaining a branch or bank affiliate in
label: BODY

text: any state in which it did not have a branch or bank affiliate before.  Thus, this Riegle-Neal Act
label: BODY

text: provision is not applicable to the Merger Application.  However, the Community Reinvestment
label: BODY

text: Act itself is applicable, as discussed below, see Part III-B.
label: BODY

text: Fifth, the proposal satisfies the adequacy of capital and management skills requirements
label: BODY

text: in the Riegle-Neal Act.  The OCC may approve an application for an interstate merger transaction
label: BODY

text: under section 1831u(a) only if each bank involved in the transaction is adequately capitalized as
label: BODY

text: of the date the application is filed and the resulting bank will continue to be adequately capitalized
label: BODY

text: and adequately managed upon consummation of the transaction.  See 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(4).
label: BODY

text: As of the date the application was filed, both Lisbon Bank and Moorhead Bank satisfied all
label: BODY

text: regulatory and supervisory requirements relating to adequate capitalization.  Currently, each bank
label: BODY

text: is at least satisfactorily managed.  The OCC has also determined that, following the merger,
label: BODY

text: Moorhead Bank will continue to exceed the standards for an adequately capitalized and adequately
label: BODY

text: managed bank.  The requirements of 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(b)(4) are therefore satisfied.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, the proposed interstate merger transaction between Lisbon Bank and
label: BODY

text: Moorhead Bank is legally permissible under section 1831u.
label: BODY

text: Following the Merger, the Resulting Bank May Retain Moorhead Bank's and Lisbon
label: BODY

text: Bank's Existing Main Offices and Branches under 12 U.S.C. §§ 36(d) & 1831u(d)(1).
label: BODY

text: The Applicants have requested that, upon the completion of the merger, Moorhead Bank
label: BODY

text: (as the resulting bank in the merger) be permitted to retain and continue to operate its existing
label: BODY

text: main office in Moorhead, Minnesota, as the main office of the resulting bank, and to retain and
label: BODY

text: operate as branches (1) its own branch and (2) the main office and branches of Lisbon Bank in
label: BODY

text: Lisbon Bank has received approval to open a branch in Fargo, North Dakota, which will not open prior to
label: BODY

text: the merger.  North Dakota law permits state-wide branching. N.D. Cent. Code § 6-03-13.1 (1996).  We note that after
label: BODY

text: the merger, Moorhead Bank, by virtue of its branches in North Dakota, would be authorized to establish and operate this
label: BODY

text: branch under 12 U.S.C. § 36(c).  As a result, the unopened branch will continue to be approved by the OCC after the
label: BODY

text: merger.
label: BODY

text: By its action in adding section 36(d), Congress made it clear that section 44(d)(1) is an express and complete
label: BODY

text: grant of office-retention authority for interstate merger transactions effected under section 44 and that it operates
label: BODY

text: independently of the provisions for branch retention in mergers under 12 U.S.C. § 36(b)(2).  Neither section 36(d) nor
label: BODY

text: section 1831u(d)(1) refers to section 36(b)(2).  Congress clearly was aware of the McFadden Act's existing provisions
label: BODY

text: for branch retention in mergers at the time it acted on section 44 and the way in which those provisions applied for
label: BODY

text: interstate national banks, since the OCC had approved interstate main office relocation transactions that also involved
label: BODY

text: mergers with affiliate banks in which the resulting bank's authority to retain branches was based on section 36(b)(2).
label: BODY

text: The Conference Report to the Riegle-Neal Act makes reference to such OCC decisions.  See H.R. Conf. Rep. No. 651,
label: BODY

text: 103d Cong., 2d Sess. 57 (1994).  By expressly providing for office-retention in section 1831u(d)(1) and then
label: BODY

text: incorporating that into the McFadden Act in section 36(d), Congress clearly intended that those provisions apply to branch
label: BODY

text: retention in interstate merger transactions under section 1831u, rather than the complex branch retention provisions of
label: BODY

text: section 36(b)(2).  Of course, section 36(b)(2) continues to govern branch retention in national bank mergers that are not
label: BODY

text: entered into under section 1831u, including mergers involving an interstate bank (such as a merger of an interstate bank
label: BODY

text: into another national bank in its home state).
label: BODY

text: North Dakota .  In an interstate merger transaction under section 1831u, the resulting bank's
label: BODY

text: retention and continued operation of the offices of the merging banks is expressly provided for:
label: BODY

text: (1)  Continued Operations. -- A resulting bank may, subject to the approval of
label: BODY

text: the appropriate Federal banking agency, retain and operate, as a main office or a
label: BODY

text: branch, any office that any bank involved in an interstate merger transaction was
label: BODY

text: operating as a main office or a branch immediately before the merger transaction.
label: BODY

text: 12 U.S.C. § 1831u(d)(1).  The resulting bank is the "bank that has resulted from an interstate
label: BODY

text: merger transaction under this section [section 1831u(a)]."  12 U.S.C. § 1831u(f)(11).  In addition,
label: BODY

text: Congress also added a conforming amendment to the McFadden Act to emphasize that branch
label: BODY

text: retention in an interstate merger transaction under section 1831u occurs under the authority of
label: BODY

text: section 1831u(d):
label: BODY

text: (d)  Branches Resulting From Interstate Merger Transactions. -- A national bank
label: BODY

text: resulting from an interstate merger transaction (as defined in section 44(f)(6) of the
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Act) may maintain and operate a branch in a State other
label: BODY

text: than the home State (as defined in subsection (g)(3)(B)) of such bank in accordance
label: BODY

text: with section 44 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act [12 U.S.C. § 1831u].
label: BODY

text: 12 U.S.C. § 36(d) (as added by Riegle-Neal Act § 102(b)(1)(B)).  Therefore, Moorhead Bank,
label: BODY

text: the resulting bank in this interstate merger transaction, may retain and continue to operate all of
label: BODY

text: the existing banking offices of both Moorhead Bank and Lisbon Bank under 12 U.S.C. §§ 36(d)
label: BODY

text: Moreover, at its branches in North Dakota and Minnesota, Moorhead Bank is authorized
label: BODY

text: to engage in all activities permissible for national banks.  See, e.g., 12 U.S.C. §§ 215a-1 (Riegle-
label: BODY

text: Neal mergers with a resulting national bank occur under the National Bank Consolidation and
label: BODY

text: Merger Act), 215a(e) (the resulting national bank in a merger succeeds to all the rights, franchises
label: BODY

text: and interests of the merging banks), & 1831u(d)(1) (continued operations at retained interstate
label: BODY

text: branches).  See also 12 U.S.C. § 36(f) (general provisions for host state laws applicable to
label: BODY

text: branches in the host state of out-of-state national banks).
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH1

text: ADDITIONAL STATUTORY AND POLICY REVIEWS
label: HH2

text: The Bank Merger Act.
label: BODY

text: The Bank Merger Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1828(c), requires the OCC's approval for any merger
label: BODY

text: between insured banks where the resulting institution will be a national bank.  Under the Act, the
label: BODY

text: OCC generally may not approve a merger which would substantially lessen competition.  In
label: BODY

text: addition, the Act also requires the OCC to take into consideration the financial and managerial
label: BODY

text: resources and future prospects of the existing and proposed institutions, and the convenience and
label: BODY

text: needs of the community to be served.  For the reasons stated below, we find the Merger
label: BODY

text: Application may be approved under section 1828(c).
label: BODY

text: Competitive Analysis
label: BODY

text: Since Moorhead Bank and Lisbon Bank are already owned by the same bank holding
label: BODY

text: company, their merger will have no anticompetitive effects.
label: BODY

text: Financial and managerial resources
label: BODY

text: The financial and managerial resources of both banks are presently satisfactory.  Moorhead
label: BODY

text: Bank expects to achieve efficiencies by operating the offices in North Dakota as branches rather
label: BODY

text: than as a separate corporate entity.  The geographic diversification of its operations will also
label: BODY

text: strengthen the combined bank.  The future prospects of the existing institutions, individually and
label: BODY

text: combined, are favorable.  Thus, we find the financial and managerial resources factor is consistent
label: BODY

text: with approval of the Merger Application.
label: BODY

text: Convenience and needs
label: BODY

text: The resulting bank will help to meet the convenience and needs of the communities to be
label: BODY

text: served.  Moorhead Bank will continue to serve the same areas in Minnesota where it has offices,
label: BODY

text: and it will add Lisbon Bank’s offices in North Dakota.  Both banks currently offer a full line of
label: BODY

text: banking services, and there will be no reductions in the products or services as a result of the
label: BODY

text: merger.  The combined bank will continue to offer a full line of banking products and services.
label: BODY

text: The branches in North Dakota will continue to engage in the same business, serving the same
label: BODY

text: communities, that Lisbon Bank is currently engaged in.
label: BODY

text: Upon completion of the merger, customers of each bank will have available to them a
label: BODY

text: greater number of branches at which to bank.  Currently, banking is not as convenient as it could
label: BODY

text: be for customers who frequently travel across the state lines or for business customers who have
label: BODY

text: operations in more than one state.  Following the merger, customers would be dealing with the
label: BODY

text: same bank in the two states and will be able to readily access their accounts with greater
label: BODY

text: convenience.  The merger will permit the resulting bank to better serve its customers and at a
label: BODY

text: lower cost.  The combined resources, including capital and reserves, of the currently separate
label: BODY

text: banks will provide a more substantial capital cushion for unexpected losses as well as provide
label: BODY

text: business customers with a higher legal lending limit.
label: BODY

text: No branch closings are contemplated as a result of this merger since the two banks serve
label: BODY

text: different areas.  However, as part of its ongoing business plans, Moorhead Bank will evaluate its
label: BODY

text: branches and, as a part of the normal course of business, may close redundant or unprofitable
label: BODY

text: branches.  Any such closures will be made in accordance with applicable statutes and regulations,
label: BODY

text: including notification of customers of the branches, and will consider the needs of the community
label: BODY

text: affected.  Accordingly, we believe the impact of the merger on the convenience and needs of the
label: BODY

text: communities to be served is consistent with approval of the Merger Application.
label: BODY

text: The Community Reinvestment Act
label: BODY

text: The Community Reinvestment Act ("CRA") requires the OCC to take into account the
label: BODY

text: applicants' record of helping to meet the credit needs of their entire communities, including low-
label: BODY

text: and moderate-income neighborhoods, when evaluating certain applications.  See 12 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: § 2903.  Lisbon Bank does not have a current CRA rating from the OCC because it recently
label: BODY

text: converted to a national bank.  Its predecessor, a state bank, had a satisfactory rating with respect
label: BODY

text: to CRA performance.  Moorhead Bank does not have a current CRA rating because it is a
label: BODY

text: relatively new charter.  No public comments were received by the OCC relating to this
label: BODY

text: Application, and the OCC has no other basis to question the banks' performance in complying
label: BODY

text: with the CRA.
label: BODY

text: The merger is not expected to have any adverse effect on the resulting bank's CRA
label: BODY

text: performance.  The resulting bank will continue to serve the same communities that the merging
label: BODY

text: banks currently serve.  Moorhead Bank will continue its current CRA programs and policies in
label: BODY

text: Minnesota.  After Lisbon Bank is merged into Moorhead Bank, its North Dakota offices will
label: BODY

text: remain open as branches of Moorhead Bank.  Moorhead Bank will carry forward the same CRA
label: BODY

text: programs and policies that the bank has today and add other programs it develops.  As a general
label: BODY

text: matter, the resulting bank will have the same commitment to helping meet the credit needs of all
label: BODY

text: the communities it serves as Moorhead Bank and Lisbon Bank have today as separate banks.  The
label: BODY

text: merger and operation of interstate branches do not alter the resulting bank's obligation to help
label: BODY

text: meet the credit needs of its communities in both states it serves.  We find that approval of the
label: BODY

text: proposed merger is consistent with the Community Reinvestment Act.
label: BODY

text: IV.
label: HH1

text: CONCLUSION AND APPROVAL
label: HH2

text: For the reasons set forth above, including the representations and commitments made by
label: BODY

text: the applicants, we find that the merger of Moorhead Bank and Lisbon Bank is legally authorized
label: BODY

text: as an interstate merger transaction under the Riegle-Neal Act, 12 U.S.C. §§ 215a-1 & 1831u(a),
label: BODY

text: the resulting bank is authorized to retain and operate the offices of both banks under 12 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: §§ 36(d) & 1831u(d)(1), and that the merger meets the other statutory criteria for approval.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, this Merger Application is hereby approved.
label: BODY

text: Steven J. Weiss
label: BODY

text: Date
label: BODY

text: Deputy Comptroller
label: BODY

text: Bank Organization and Structure
label: BODY

text: Application Control Number:  97-MW-02-0040
label: BODY
